channel.title: Obsidian Vault

item.title: Common and Proper Nouns
item.description:
The difference between a common and a proper What is a Noun? is general and specific things.



Uppercase is bolded
Lower case is also bolded*
Mountains are my favourite.
Everest is my favourite mountain.
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Nouns/Common and Proper Nouns.md

item.title: Concrete and Abstract Nouns
item.description:
Concrete means Physical.
Something you can interact with, ex: A ball.
Abstract means Not Psychical (Away and Drawn).
Something you can't physical interact with, ex: Sadness.
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Nouns/Concrete and Abstract Nouns.md

item.title: Singular and Plural Nouns
item.description:
A What is a Noun? can be Singular (Single) and Plural (Plus / More).

Example: Singular to Plural
By adding an "s" to the word makes it plural.
Dog = Dogs
Cat = Cats
Dinosaur = Dinosaurs
Whale = Whales

Example: Singular to Plural
You will have to remember
Leaf = Leaves
Child = Children
Fungus = Fungi
Mouse = Mice
Sheep = Sheep
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Nouns/Singular and Plural Nouns.md

item.title: What is a Noun?
item.description:
People (living things), Places, Things and Ideas.
Example: (noun is in bold)
This is Raul.
He is from Argentina.
He is a penguin.
Raul has big Dreams.
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Nouns/What is a Noun?.md

item.title: The Future Tense
item.description:
We commonly use will to represent the future.

A simple way to change from present to future is to add will before the verb. (make sure it looks right)
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Verb/Verb Tense/The Future Tense.md

item.title: The Past Tense
item.description: Adding -ed to the end of the verb to make it happen in the past.
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Verb/Verb Tense/The Past Tense.md

item.title: The Present Tense
item.description:
Things that happen in the present moment, ex: I eat a donut.

I eat a donut. (right now!)
Louise doesn't want a donut. (right now)
The water is super cold. (right now)
Alex is singing in the shower. (right now)
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Verb/Verb Tense/The Present Tense.md

item.title: What is Verb Tense?
item.description: A Verb can happen in the Past, in the Present and the Future.
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Verb/Verb Tense/What is Verb Tense?.md

item.title: Action, Linking and Helping Verbs
item.description:
Action verbs describe action! Is the subject of the verb actually doing something? If so, then we're dealing with an action verb.

She ran
They said
He clapped
Linking verbs describe a "state of being". If the verb describes what the subject is like, then we're dealing with a linking verb.

Flowers smell nice
Tennis seems hard
Alice is tall
Helping verbs help us form tenses and moods, describing when an action occurs or if the action is possible. Helping verbs must be part of a larger verb phrase.

I can't believe it
They were dancing
She has practiced
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Verb/Action, Linking and Helping Verbs.md

item.title: Verb Aggrement
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Verb/Verb Aggrement.md

item.title: What is a Verb?
item.description:
Verbs can show action.

The bear roars.
The bear runs.
The bear sleeps.

Verbs can be a state of being or an action.
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/Parts of Speech/Verb/What is a Verb?.md

item.title: Adverb
item.description: An adverb is a word that modifies a verb, an adjective, or another adverb. It often tells you how, when, where, or to what extent something happens.

item.title: Adjective Clause
item.description:
An Adjective Clause starts with a relative pronoun.

When used to define and identify, no comma is used.
When used to modify a main clause, a comma is used

These can be used as subject and the conjunction.

That
Which
Who
These can only be used as the relative pronoun (the conjunction)
Whom
Whose
When
Where
Why

Independent Clause: The man lives next door.
While it can stand alone, we don't get much information, which is why we will use an adjective clause to Identify the man.
Complex sentence: The man who lives next door is a doctor.
Because we are using the adjective clause to identify the man and define him, there is no comma.

The Difference between who and whom is that who can be used as a subject whilst whom is only an object.
You can NEVER use whom with a verb. If you see whom in an adjective clause it isn't the subject.
Complex sentence: Dr. Smith, who lives next door, is a retired surgeon.
Its in brackets because its modifying the main clause providing more information, but its not necessary. The reason we don't need to identify him is because Dr. Smith is a proper noun, which is specific making the adjective clause optional.

Jerry (went) to the same store where Jennifer (bought) her couch.
Frank (went) to Study in Boston, where some of the world's best universities are based.

item.title: Adverb Clause
item.description:
The Adverb Clause acts as the Adverb.
An Adverb is a word that modifies a verb, an adjective, or another adverb. It often tells you how, when, where, or to what extent something happens.

item.title: Noun Clause
item.description:
A Noun clause acts as the Noun in a sentence.
Types of Noun Clauses Clauses

Example: Whatever you ask (must be appropriate for the class).
When the Noun Clause is a subject it is always in front of the sentence.

Example: I know (what you did last summer.)
When a Noun Clause is a direct object it comes after the action verb/state verb.

Example: My worst fault is (what you identified).
is is a linking verb which is what predict nouns come after.

If you flip the predict noun to be before the linking verb and the main clause after and it makes sense then it is definitely a predicate noun.

Noun Clauses act as objects to prepositions like on, about, or for. Together the preposition and its object form a prepositional phrase.
Our suspect depends on who owns the murder weapon. 
The people want to hear about why youâ€™re running for congress
Common ones include for ,and, my, with

item.title: How I format notes.
item.description:
Underline means subject
Highlighted means verb
Bold or (Brackets) means dependent/subordinate clause
Quick Note: means important information
item.guid: English Grammar Notes/How I format notes..md
